Award.AwardTitle: Nanomanufacturing of Biopolymer Nanofiber Hierarchical Assemblies

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Immediate cellular environment, commonly referred to as the extracellular matrix, consists of micro/nanofibers (diameter: microns to sub-100 nanometers) and serves as a scaffold upon which most cells in the body attach and receive mechanical and chemical cues. An increased awareness of the role of alignment in extracellular matrix-cell interactions and the role of biophysical cues in development and disease models including cancer has necessitated the development of fiber manufacturing technologies mimicking the native environments for in vivo translational and in vitro cell behavior studies. Electrospinning is the most commonly used manufacturing method to fabricate nanofibers. However, it still lacks precise control on fiber diameter, spacing and orientation. This award utilizes a non-electrospinning fiber manufacturing platform to architect precise biophysical environments for cell studies through improved spinnability of biopolymers with control on fiber diameter, spacing and orientation in multiple layers. The resulting constructs can be instrumental in developing implantable scaffolds for tissue engineering, and single cell diagnostic platforms. Therefore, results from this research will benefit the U.S. economy and society. This multidisciplinary research involves elements from disciplines such as manufacturing, polymer physics, biology, mechanics and mechanical engineering. The award will help broaden participation of underrepresented groups in engineering research and positively impact engineering education at both undergraduate and graduate levels.

The physics of polymer fiber formation at the nanoscale involves a delicate balance between solution rheology and applied external forces, which makes nanomanufacturing and hierarchical assembly of nanofibers extremely challenging. To augment our capabilities in fiber manufacturing, a non-electrospinning nanofiber manufacturing platform will be used to study fiber spinnability in this work. Due to elimination of electric source in the manufacturing process, the platform will provide superior control on fiber diameter, orientation, spacing and assembly, particularly in multiple layers. Using poly (lactic-co-glycolide acid) and fibrinogen as model polymer systems, this project will develop fiber spinnability scaling laws representing fiber diameter design space spanning a wide range of solution rheologies and processing parameters. Furthermore, mechanical tensile testing of single fibers using atomic force microscopy at different strain rates will provide the fiber probability failure Weibull distributions in the manufacturing process. This research will fill the knowledge gap on the spinnability of biopolymers and for the first time provide the ability to manufacture custom architectures representing gradients in biophysical cues. The overall research will thus provide a roadmap to design and build scaffolds of biopolymers with improved quality, scalability and repeatability.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research findings from this proposal demonstrate nanomanufacturing of fiber networks of biocompatible and biopolymer fibers with control on diameter, spacing, and orientation in single and multiple layers. We develop multi-layer fiber networks of a variety of biocompatible (Poly (D,L-lactide-co-glycolide)(PLGA) and Poly-ethylene oxide (PEO)) and biopolymers (Hyaluronic acid (HA), Fibrinogen and Gelatin). We further develop the fiber spinnability design space spanning polymer solution concentrations of PLGA (fiber diameter 200-5000nm) and HA (200-500 nm).

To determine the mechanical properties of fibers, we have developed a new method to characterize individual nanofibers. Tensile testing of parallel fiber arrays of tightly controlled diameters at different strain rates quantifies material modulus to be diameter dependent. Modeling the fiber arrays as springs in parallel (6, 10, 14 and 30 fibers), allows us to extend the mechanical characterization to the nanoscale, thus providing a new method to characterize the fragile polymer nanofibers.

Multi-layer nanofibrous architectures were created by depositing fibers of controlled diameters at specific spacing to quantitate cell behavior. Using a parallel network of fibers interfaced with monolayers, we recapitulated the invasion of cells from monolayers in single, chain and collective modes as described in in vivo literature. We also identified suspended gap closure depended upon both the shape (oval or circle) and size of the gaps, with smaller gaps < 85,000 μm2 closing independent of shape, while those between 85000-140000 μm2 closed only for oval gaps, and gaps larger than 140,000 μm2 did not close for both shapes (Figure 1). We developed crosshatch network of fibers of varied interfiber spacing: (dense ~ 3 and 6 μm, intermediate ~ 18 and 36 μm, and wide ~ 54 μm) to study migrational and cytoskeletal plasticity (Figure 2). Unexpectedly, we found that cells on dense networks had elongated shapes and migrated at high speeds persistently similar to cells on anisotropic parallel network of fibers. On intermediate networks, cells behaved similar to 2D flat substrates, and on wide networks, cells were observed to be near-stationary in kite shapes. Dense 3 μm networks caused cancer cells to have 3D shapes due to poorly developed f-actin stress fibers and thick nuclei, a signature of invasive potential. To study individual protrusions, we created fiber networks with mismatch of diameters (base fiber ~ 2000 nm, and protrusive fiber ~ 100, 200 and 600 nm). This design constrained cell migration along the larger base fibers while allowing cells to form protrusions on protrusive fibers (Figure 3). To determine if protrusions were formed similarly on flat substrates, we developed a new manufacturing method to deposit flat ribbons of equivalent widths and showed that flat 2D substrates are unable to capture the protrusive sensitivity to round fibers. We also demonstrated a diminished role of intermediate filament vimentin in protrusion dynamics. We extended the diameter mismatch strategy to identify that cells biophysically sensed curvature by coiling (wrapping-around) on fibers (Figure 4). The coiling width increased with fiber diameter and interestingly breast cancer cells were found to form wider coil widths compared to their non-tumorigenic counterparts.

The research strategy and methods developed in this proposal trained multiple graduate students and undergraduate students including minority students in manufacturing, material characterization and use of nanofibers. The findings from our research have been widely disseminated through podium and poster presentations at conferences and published in peer-review journals.

Modified by: Amrinder S Nain

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1. (i) Aligned parallel fibers to study cell invasion followed by gap closure. Scale bar 200 ?m. (ii) Cell invasion in single, chain or collective mode depends upon fiber diameter and fiber spacing. Scale bar 25 ?m (iii) Design of fiber networks to engineer non-closing gaps. Scale bar 500 ?m.
    Sharma, P.; Ng, C.; Jana, A.; Padhi, A.; Szymanski, P.; Lee, J. S. H.; Behkam, B.; Nain, A. S. Aligned Fibers Direct Collective Cell Migration to Engineer Closing and Non-Closing Wound Gaps. Mol. Biol. Cell 2017, 28, 2579?2588.
    Public Domain
    Amrinder S Nain
    Figure 1
  • Figure 2. (A) Dense, intermediate, and wide fiber networks. Scale bars in ?m. (B) Cells on dense networks migrate persistently in elongated shapes, while intermediate networks recapitulate 2D migration. (C) Fiber networks regulate cell behavior and morphology.
    Jana A., Nookaew I., Singh J., Behkam B., Franco A., and Nain A. S., ?Crosshatch nanofiber networks of tunable interfiber spacing induce plasticity in cell migration and cytoskeleton response?, The FASEB journal, In press 2019. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1096/fj.201900131R
    Public Domain
    Amrinder S Nain
    Figure 2
  • Figure 3. (A) Mismatch of diameters allows study of individual protrusions. Scale bar 20 ?m. (B) Protrusion morphologies are different on round fibers vs. flat ribbons. Scale bars are1 ?m for flat fiber and 20 ?m otherwise. (C)Vimentin localization occurs only in broad protrusions.
    Koons, B.; Sharma, P.; Ye, Z.; Mukherjee, A.; Lee, M. H.; Wirtz, D.; Behkam, B.; Nain, A. S. Cancer Protrusions on a Tightrope: Nanofiber Curvature Contrast Quantitates Single Protrusion Dynamics. ACS Nano 2017, 11, 12037?12048.
    Public Domain
    Amrinder S Nain
    Figure 3
  • Figure 4. (A) Cells coil on round fibers and coiling width depends upon the fiber diameter. (B) Metastatic breast cancer cells (MDA-MB-231) have significantly larger coil widths compared to their non-tumorigenic (MCF-10A) counterparts. Scale bar 10 ?m.
    Mukherjee A., Behkam B., and Nain A. S., ?Cancer cells sense fibers by coiling on them in a curvature dependent manner?. In Press iScience. DOI: 10.1016/j.isci.2019.08.023
    Amrinder S Nain
    Figure 4
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Research findings from this proposal demonstrate nanomanufacturing of fiber networks of biocompatible and biopolymer fibers with control on diameter, spacing, and orientation in single and multiple layers. We develop multi-layer fiber networks of a variety of biocompatible (Poly (D,L-lactide-co-glycolide)(PLGA) and Poly-ethylene oxide (PEO)) and biopolymers (Hyaluronic acid (HA), Fibrinogen and Gelatin). We further develop the fiber spinnability design space spanning polymer solution concentrations of PLGA (fiber diameter 200-5000nm) and HA (200-500 nm). To determine the mechanical properties of fibers, we have developed a new method to characterize individual nanofibers. Tensile testing of parallel fiber arrays of tightly controlled diameters at different strain rates quantifies material modulus to be diameter dependent. Modeling the fiber arrays as springs in parallel (6, 10, 14 and 30 fibers), allows us to extend the mechanical characterization to the nanoscale, thus providing a new method to characterize the fragile polymer nanofibers. Multi-layer nanofibrous architectures were created by depositing fibers of controlled diameters at specific spacing to quantitate cell behavior. Using a parallel network of fibers interfaced with monolayers, we recapitulated the invasion of cells from monolayers in single, chain and collective modes as described in in vivo literature. We also identified suspended gap closure depended upon both the shape (oval or circle) and size of the gaps, with smaller gaps < 85,000 μm2 closing independent of shape, while those between 85000-140000 μm2 closed only for oval gaps, and gaps larger than 140,000 μm2 did not close for both shapes (Figure 1). We developed crosshatch network of fibers of varied interfiber spacing: (dense ~ 3 and 6 μm, intermediate ~ 18 and 36 μm, and wide ~ 54 μm) to study migrational and cytoskeletal plasticity (Figure 2). Unexpectedly, we found that cells on dense networks had elongated shapes and migrated at high speeds persistently similar to cells on anisotropic parallel network of fibers. On intermediate networks, cells behaved similar to 2D flat substrates, and on wide networks, cells were observed to be near-stationary in kite shapes. Dense 3 μm networks caused cancer cells to have 3D shapes due to poorly developed f-actin stress fibers and thick nuclei, a signature of invasive potential. To study individual protrusions, we created fiber networks with mismatch of diameters (base fiber ~ 2000 nm, and protrusive fiber ~ 100, 200 and 600 nm). This design constrained cell migration along the larger base fibers while allowing cells to form protrusions on protrusive fibers (Figure 3). To determine if protrusions were formed similarly on flat substrates, we developed a new manufacturing method to deposit flat ribbons of equivalent widths and showed that flat 2D substrates are unable to capture the protrusive sensitivity to round fibers. We also demonstrated a diminished role of intermediate filament vimentin in protrusion dynamics. We extended the diameter mismatch strategy to identify that cells biophysically sensed curvature by coiling (wrapping-around) on fibers (Figure 4). The coiling width increased with fiber diameter and interestingly breast cancer cells were found to form wider coil widths compared to their non-tumorigenic counterparts. The research strategy and methods developed in this proposal trained multiple graduate students and undergraduate students including minority students in manufacturing, material characterization and use of nanofibers. The findings from our research have been widely disseminated through podium and poster presentations at conferences and published in peer-review journals.
